												Don't let the idea that you can purchase premium currency with in game gold fool you, this game is pay 2 win. If you're high level (50+), you can earn enough gold to pay for a premium membership (or royal blessing, as it's called), but there's much more to be had with premium currency. More backspack in your tiny backpack? Pay up. Per item type (equipment, loot, potions, quest items). Would you like to revive instantly? Pay up. Fast travel for no gold? Pay up. Pet collars? Pay up. In fact, you're constantly nagged with functionality that requires you to either get a premium membership or pay a one time fee in premium currency. Constantly.If you don't have a premium membership, you receive a lot less gold, experience and loot. Your resurrecting sickness lasts seven times longer, and much much more.The game itself is alright. There are tons of different spells, and different classes really do feel like different classes. Some quests are unique and interesting, but most are fetch, deliver or kill quests. The PVP wasn't well thought through, and can be tedious at times. Most areas look similar, and enemies are not very unique in the way they act.The chat is horrendous and unintuitive. This leads to very little chatter over the airways and a sort of isolated feeling, as if you're not really in an mmorpg.Overall, the relentless pushing to get you to pay up spoils most of the fun, especially since your basic account is so limited it's hard not to feel pressured into spending money. I can't recommend it.

												For all those calling this P2W you need to quit reviewing F2P games, you have no clue how F2P works. Every MMO F2P game has microtransactions. Someone has to pay for server upkeep and development, in short no F2P MMO will ever be truly free.The upper hand Royal Quest has over it's competitors is that over 95% of what can be bought with cash can also be sold in the in game market for gold. Collecting gold in game is also very easy for players who do not want to pay any cash into the game. Even the cash shop currency can be sold. So it gives no advantage to any players that prefer to buy cash shop items.This is actually a great game and THE MOST BALANCED F2P with cash shop items I have ever played and I have played them all, literally. I am sick of the all the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor reviews of games by players who don't have enough knowledge into said game to give it an factual review. So let's clear up some of these misconceptions already put out there for this particular game:1. Bag space. Your bag upon starting is split into 5 sections with 14 spaces each, that is 70 slots total. I've played plenty of "F2P" MMORPG's with less.2. There is no forced PVP Zones. You can choose to follow your open world quests and grind or you can join the sandbox PVP zone for boosted EXP points.3. EVERYTHING except the market currency can be bought at different NPC's, INCLUDING CASH SHOP ITEMS AND MOUNTS FOR IN GAME CURRENCY! One of the best mounts in the game cannot even be bought, it has to be unlocked with quest items. You don't have to buy these items just from players. Cash shop currency can be bought through the auction house . And they have included a maximum/minimum cap on how much a player can charge for cash shop currency. This is to fight gold farming companies. IN WHICH CASE NO OTHER "F2P" game has ever initiated a limiting system like this and has actually done very well for this game. You won't ever go into town seeing shouts of "Golds 200k=9.00 US @ royalquestgolds.com" or some garbage along those lines.4. You don't have to pay anything to get in as some other review has mentioned.5. Another reviewer had mentioned getting constantly killed by another player with OP cash shop gear. You cannot buy gear in the cash shop for this game. You cannot buy the ingredients in the cash shop to craft gear. This RPG much like every other RPG is heavily character build based. I haven't purchased **** since I first started playing and was already dropping characters 10 levels higher in the PVP zone in the most basic gear I could pick up. Also in which case PVP zones are limited by levels also so no getting into battles at level 13 with level 47 characters. PVP Zones are level designated & only allow a 10 level difference. 6. Now with the newest update all classes are about balanced in PVP. The crusader for a time there was a tad bit horrible but the new update has fixed that.7. No kill stealing, no powerleveling. Everyone who hits an enemy will gain their proper share of exp from it. Even if you are not partied with that/those other person/people. However who ever does the most total damage will get the loot. All characters in a party with the exception of PVP zones, since parties can get split up in the zone, must hit the targets to get exp from it. No letting another character stand aside gaining EXP while a higher level character decimates the battlefield. Each person must attack to get their exp share. Again another way to combat gold farms & their services. In the PVP zones however, you will get exp from ally kills no matter where you are and the total end exp when you leave the zone is what you truly get, it is not split up dismally between the party when you leave. What you see is what you  get.8. All mobs that can aggro will be aggro'd. A system in Royal Quest needed in most MMORPG's to eliminate people's needs for vacuum hacking. If you run past 20 aggro set monsters in Royal Quest you will pull 20 aggro set monsters. At that point it's fight or flight. Which can make for some interesting save-your-***-moments. Had another character try &  run past me pulling roughly 10 monsters, he ended up dying right next to me and in an instant they were set on me.9. There is no such thing as junk in Royal Quest. Everything you pick up can and will be used for crafting something or commission(repeatable) quests which give Exp/gold/items sometimes all 3 and a few of them give a cash shop item. Even not so great gear can be broken down for crafting materials. Which makes making money in the game so easy. There is always somebody looking for what you have. And as I had mentioned earler more than 95% of cash shop items are sellable in the market. There really is no upper hand for cash users, unless you think that NO bonus stat costume is giving the player at the controls an ego boost...(At this time there are only 4 total pieces of costumes/pets/decorations that give bonus stats, which are horrible compared to the stats you can get from crafting normally).10. Fair level up system for those of us who work. Your character gains 2x exp points when you are offline resting. The exp amount is dependant on your character level. Fetch, kill and collect quests are pretty fair in ratio at each level. So for collect quests which take the most time you can grind for a little bit, collect the money then buy the necessary collection items in the market/auction house.It is your standard point & click, press skill button, type of game. Lightweight on processor and graphic usage. For those that prefer WASD movement like myself...as someone else had mentioned, the point and click system absolutely sucks. Because of this, I would compare this game to a cross between point & click ease of Diablo, skill system of Dekaron, and speed of Dragon Nest (When you get into higher levels of course). Some AoE's have a targeting system similiar to that of Wildstar. Camera movement is very Diablo-esque, which can also be annoying sometimes. This game could also use a better guide on how to obtain certain types of currency in game for specific NPC's, and NO, none of this special currency cannot be bought in the cash shop. HOWEVER, ONE WARNING: This game has been in open beta for over 2 years now(Yeah, I know that is rather ridcilulous.). So be prepared for major changes that could be postive or negative.Update as of 07-24-16 I can no longer recommend this game due to it's unchanged model & extremely slow updates I have moved on to Eloa (Hosted by Webzen), Devilian (Hosted by Trion), & HeroWarZ (Hosted by Kog Games). These 3 games are much better 2.5D games.  Eloa being the most similiar to RQ but with much more content and much less push for Cash Shop items. Also Eloa uses a unique "Stance" system that allows certain skills & weapons in certain stances for each class. As well as your pets help combat enemies in the realm. Even better WSAD or Click to move are options. Sadly this is not a suite (Steam, Arc, Origin, Aeria Ignite) game, so the population is not great at this point.

TOP QUESTION: Is this game P2W (Pay to Win)ANSWER: The short answer is NO, however, let me go in depth with this...When you start this game you get 3 days free premium this gives you:+50% EXPERIENCE AND DROP RATEPORTAL SKILL (This allows you to save 5 places and teleport to it at any time including Maidens (Rogues/Assassin/Thief get a skill called Secret Lair which allows you to save only one spot but its free!)).FREE TELEPORTATION BETWEEN MAIDENS (Even without premium it doesn't cost that much)+10 QUESTS IN QUEST LOG (I have never needed 30 quest slots even at low levels where I had 18 quests at one time, even with dailies (I will go more in depth into the dailies later on).PETS AND MOUNTSPets are utility centric as in they do nothing but pick up drops for you they do require you buy SIlver/Gold Magnet Collars from Cash Shop, they have a durability called Charge, 1 Charge = 1 drop picked up (Pets are not worth the trouble having other than aesthetics you can easily just pick up the drops yourself with spacebar).Mounts again are utility centric they offer increased movespeed as well as various stat boost such as attack or health, they require Mount Feed from Cash Shop, Crusader/Dark Knight can get Mounts that do not require food for 300G from Ricker in Varlone City he is in the centre square off to the top right and from Ronda in Iris out of the South Gate of Varlone, these Mounts only give movespeed bonus (Mounts are semi useful for all classes as the buffs from them last for 1 hour even if you dismount, only the classes I mentioned can do mounted combat). You can also use Grass Chewing Gum which gives you 20% Runspeed for 15 minutes, you can get it from a daily quest or dropped from monsters (its rare to get a drop), you can also buy it from the Market fairly cheap.A Mount and a Pet can be bought from an NPC (Head of the Merchant Guild) to the south of city square in Varlone City.Reales can be bought from Market for 10-14k gold per Reale, 10x Mount Feed is 29 Reales and last for 1 hour each (290-406k for 10 hours of extra buffs, which you totally dont need if you are just PVMing although it would be useful), Silver Collar 2000 Charge is the same 29 Reales. You can get 100x Mount Feed for 269 Reales and Gold Collar 9000 Charge for 99 Reales. This is on the EU Maragorne Server.BAGS AND WAREHOUSEYou have 14 slots for each type of item they are split into Equipment, Expendables, Loot and Crafting Items. You can store excess/rare items in your Warehouse which has 27 slots available accessible at any Maiden. The 2 Bags that get full fairly quickly are Expendables and Loot but once you learn what you should keep and what should be sold to NPC or put on the Market you won't have too many bag problems.EQUIPMENT, ITEM IMPROVEMENT AND SEALINGALL Equipment in the game can either be bought from NPCs, Crafted, Dropped from Monsters, Found in Dungeons (Marked by a Cross Shaped Grave Stone with Blue particle effects, these are mostly personal so you will not be able to sell them on the Market) or bought from Players via the Market.Item improvement is done through Alchemists you will know the NPC is an Alchemist because they will have an Alchemical Cauldron next to them which is used to craft recipes. Philosopher Stone Chips are used to upgrade C Class Equipments only, Philosopher Stone Shards are used to upgrade B and A Class Equipments. Ashkalot Cubes can be used to upgrade any item while reducing its cost and protecting it from breaking (there is a daily to get these cubes), Cash Shop items can help in your upgrading but if you start using those before level 40 you are just wasting your money.Sealing is EXPENSIVE, this allows your equipment to gain extra stats quality of seal is as follows from worst to best Green/Blue/Purple/Orange. Emeralds are used to seal C Class Equipments, Sapphires for B Class Equipments and Morions for A Class Equipments. Crystal Vessels can be obtained through a daily quest, this item can be used to grant you Blood Crystal which can be used to place a new seal on an already sealed item (The current seal will be DELETED and a NEW seal put on). Emerald, Sapphire, Morion and Crystal Vessels can be purchased from Master of Enchantment outside of Academy of Magic Varlone City bottom right of map. Cash Shop items only help to alter the seals already on the equipment or to allow the lowest quality of Blue to be added.DAILIES AND X2 EXPERIENCEThere will be many dailies but the two worth mentioning are Caustic Acid (This nets you 3 Ashkolot Cubes for 50 Caustic Acid) and Green Slime (This nets you 2 Crystal Vessels for 50 Green Slimes), you can take these quests soon after you hit level 20 from the Message Board in Varlone City centre to the bottom right. You can also get a free Emerald along with 2 Potions from Protecting the Vegetable Garden from Pests taken from Connor Barr in Elgore. You can bring up available quests by hitting the M or Q key and clicking the Available Quests tab top right (You will need to bring up the map and click this tab and quest to see where to go for it each time you lose your way).You will gain resting bonus experience if you are not on your character for more than 8 hours to a max of 20 hours this works on all quests and monsters you gain experience from will be doubled till it is depleted.BELLA THE RARITY BUYER AND SELLA THE COLLECTORCards are rare drops from monsters which can be given to Bella for Insignia's of Distinction or sold on the Market. Various items can be bought from Sella for Insignia's of Distinction including PREMIUM TIME as well as a few things that can be bought in Cash Shop which includes Decorations that give +5% Health. They are both located in centre court of Varlone City to the northwest. You can also gain Insignia's of Distinction by PVPing in PVM/PVP areas Rewards are given monthly and you must be in the top 20 PVPers.CRAFTINGMost loots are used for crafting, C Class Equipments are 100%, B Class 80% and A Class 60%. Flax is important in crafting you find this randomly by digging up plants. Ores are also found scattered around areas and as you progress through the game you will find the higher quality ores, digging ores also gets you Anthricite. Elum is obtained through Equipment that you put in the Splitter, the higher level the Equipment the more Elum you will get, Red Elum comes from Weapons, Blue Elum comes from Clothing (Armor, Headgear etc), Green Elum comes from Accessories (Rings, Amulets etc). So keep those Equipment drops! if you plan on crafting (Crafting gets you personal gear with slots, the same as Dungeons). WARNING keep all Gem drops if you do plan on crafting as they drop rarely and are used in recipes at high levels. Some Crafting Recipes can be bought from NPCs inside of PVM/PVP areas, they require you gather Elenium nodes which will give you Alchemical Runes with which to buy the Recipes. Recipes also drop from monsters. You can find all the machines necessary for crafting/splitting at the east side of Varlone City, SPECIAL NOTE the Elenium Converter requires Alchemical Runes to change 1 material to another.PVP FIGHTING ARENAPushing A on your keyboard brings up a Menu with Battleground, Arena and Store (in the Center, Blue button), You can join Arena 5 times a day to earn Blood Tokens which in turn can be used to buy from the Arena Store to improve your prowess vs other players, there is also a Mount and Pet as well as various potions.To conclude the game is beautiful the music is great and I enjoy playing it for free.I hope you found this Review(Guide) informative and insightful.Go here for more!All about RQ and MORE![eu.royalquest.com]HAPPY RQing!

Everything in the game, yes, EVERYTHING, can be purchased with gold. If somoene buys an item with real money, they can sell it for in game gold, and people frequently do.  This is one of the best systems of any free to play ive ever seen.  If you dont feel like spending 5$ to get a "real money" item, just wait til someone else buys it and sells it.  You can just get enough in game gold to buy it off them when you want!I could continue, going on and on about the game in paragraph form, but ill simply list the Pros and Cons.PROS:- Fantastic Music- Responsive/noncomplicated UI- Veried Environments and Enemies- Varied Missions and mission rewards- Tons of weapons, hats, shirts, pants, shoes, etc; all with unique stats- Gear Upgrading system. (Find a reall nice piece of gear? Upgrade it and make it better!)- Lack of Pay-to-Win Elements- Devs are active! They do announcements in game, as well as work on updates, and help players who are having issues.- Fantastic community. If youre a new player, 99% of the community will answer any question you have and try to help you along the way!----------------------------CONS:- Occasional bugs, but nothing major- Bag size is relatively small to start with (this can be expanded at any time)- Some Quests have you running across large portions of the map, and you move slowly at first (better gear can fix this "problem")- Game is still in Beta. (This will obviously change, leading up to the full release)----------------------------Honestly I only made this review because the current top rated reviews for the game are completely inaccurate.  Most of the people who reviewed the game and then said "PAY TO WIN DONT PLAY IT LOL" are completely wrong.  They invested just enough time to get to about level 15 (not even to the first major choice you make in the game, which branch of your class you want to advance into) and then declared the game unbalanced.Not only is this completely false (as i said above, someone can, and people constantly do, buy "real money" currency and sell it on the in game market for gold. I want to start by saying that I have a max rank (Lv. 60) character and a guild I've personally founded by myself. I do love this game, it's very addicting. 												I'm sort of confused by some of the negative reviews, as I'm finding this to be a pretty decent game that doesn't have many problems.First, it has a lot of lore and story to it.  It's not just quests like "Kill 10 rats because I stubbed my toe and need toe medicine" - the quests have more detail and story to them than that.  Each quest has been pretty detailed so far with lots of extra tidbits of story and lore you can get out of the NPCs if you select to ask them certain questions.You also find a lot of NPCs that aren't part of the quest line but that actually have story bits to add if you talk to them.  I find this extra work and detail to help the game to be much more immersive.The classes are all very different.  If you don't like the way one plays, you really should try the others as they all have their own different way to play and their own feel.  The powers are all different and specific for each class line and greatly change and affect the way you play.  This isn't like some games where the only difference in classes and skills are that they make a different graphic for them but they play the same way.  Here they all really play in specific unique ways.  Even when two classes have traps, one class they are auto traps and the other are traps you manually detonate.  There are a pretty good amount of skills too and they all have purpose and do different things rather than just being damage upgrades that look a little different.The game plays out just fine and quickly.  Yes, your main attack if you click something is set on default to autoattack (like 99.9% of every MMORPG that exists, so why one would complain about that I don't know - especially since you can toggle it off to manual if you really want) but in most classes that attack is very fast and you're going to be worried about using all your skills all through combat.  You quickly end up using a lot of them.  The only class that plays a little slower to start out is the Warrior, but even they end up with a lot of skills in time too.  If you're into melee and want faster combat, play the Rogue.  The Warrior is meant to actually be a party tank and has a lot of taunts and things instead of the fast pace skills of the other classes.  That isn't to say they are lacking, they have quite a few and you'll see them as you level up more.The game isn't well known here, so there aren't a lot of people in game right now.  Not only that, but they don't really understand why it's a free game they can't get in (the first week is just for people who buy one of the DLC packs, but they only say that if you go searching elsewhere to find that info and didn't post that here).I'm not that into PvP, but for people who are they have these nice castles your guild can take over that spawn chests of loot and have other neat little extras in them.I don't really get their whole "PvPvE" thing - that's just a fancy way to say PvP zones.  Most MMORPG games with PvP also have monsters in the same zones but they just call them PvP zones instead of trying to be fancy with the wording.  I really very much dislike PvP and want to avoid it, so I'll have to see how much it affects my gameplay as I level up.  I hope it's avoidable and not too too bad.  A description at their web site says there are quests in those areas which I never enjoy being forced to go to PvP zones to do quests, especially in game that has so much story and I really am enjoying reading all the quest text.  I'm not really there yet though to see how that's going to affect my play.  It could have a huge negative affect for me and even get me to quit if it's bad enough but I'll just have to wait to get there to see.The camera angles really aren't that bad.  I think they limited it in order to make the game work better on lesser systems, I'm not sure.  It runs very smooth and pretty though and I don't really see why they can't allow you to pan it so you can see into the distance a little more but you do have some tilt control and it's really not too bad.The one thing I dislike though and very much want to see change is for us to get the ability to use WASD movement in the game.  A lot of games like this launch with click to move movement only, and it's always the same.  I get sick of clicking so much, it's a pain in the butt after a while.  They really need to change the game to allow keyboard movement controls as well.  I know it doesn't work great for every situation, like if people set the camera to auto movement, but they could always disable it if you have auto camera on or find some other work around.  Too many people are going to want WASD movement controls, maybe they'll listen and put them in game in time though.So I'm finding a pretty decent game here.  You may want to wait and not chance it, and give it another 4 or 5 days until it's opened for free to everybody, but I for one am very happy with the game as it is and am glad I bought a DLC pack so I could play now.  Even if PvP areas make me quit later (again I still don't know if they will or not, it depends if I can still level and quest around without having to deal with them for the most part) - I still will be happy that I got and played the game.  It's been interesting and fun and is a good example of how to put real story and more meaning into quests.  It also is doing something very right with the skill system all being so different.  Hopefully once it's opened for free a lot of people will find out just how much they like it too.The video they have here really doesn't show much of the game, you can find videos elsewhere online of people playing the game if you really want to see how it plays though.  They don't take the time to read and go through all the extra text and things in those videos however, so if you're a person who really likes story and lore in your games you won't really see how cool it is until you're able to get in there yourself.

												This game is really fun. I don't understand how people are voting it down because you have to click to move. Like, have you played Diablo/Torchlight? Get over it. Anyway, back to the game:It's an MMO, so be prepared for a lot of fetch quests. Besides this, it does some pretty unique things. First of which would be the leveling system. It's typical in the sense that every level you get stat points and sometimes a talent point, but the stat system is really cool. basically, every 10 points put into a specific stat, you get an extra bonus to it, and your 'rank' in that stat increases. So if I put 10 points into stamina, which is the rangers base stat, I'll get +15 to my damage output, on top of the points I put into it. Very unique and I enjoy ranking up stats.The talent point system is also fairly unique, as they're all passives. There are multiple paths to travel down, which each give your class a unique playstyle. I'm not sure if there's a way to reset these, but I'm sure there is. This game is NOT pay to win. You can obtain the premium currency by using gold, the in-game currency. Actually, gold is pretty easy to obtain as well, and so are most of the items in the game. It could be a bit of a grind, but that's how most MMOs work anyway, so it's not a big deal. I really have been enjoying my time with this game. It's fun, it's a good time waster, and it feels like there's been a lot of love and time put into it, in order to make it good. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun MMO to play with.

I know my review is 'negative', but this is not really a bad game.  I just don't think people should bother playing it on Steam for a few reasons.  As far as I know, you cannot link your account from the official Royal Quest forums to your Steam account.  Which means you need to download the game all over again if you want to use the free promotional stuff.  Or even talk on their forums, because you have to pick a character you have created in the game to give your profile an actual name (instead of the generic one you are given when you create an account) or to actually post anything at all on their forum. Another issue I have is the camera does not follow the character around very well at all.  It can be disorienting and frustrating having to constantly move it around, even after having ticked the option in the menu to make the camera follow you.  It slides very slowly around your character while you move around, and doesn't look good or act very well at all.You have no option to move with W,A,S,D keys.  Only the mouse.  It's not a a deal breaker for me, personally.  But I would rather be able to move with the keys then having to hold the mouse down all the time or clicking from one spot to another.  Plus with how wonky the camera is, it just adds to the over all feeling of frustration with this game.It gives you tips and guides you, but it doesn't.  You have a tutorial you can go through to understand things a little better, but it doesn't really explain everything.  Like, everything you pick up says LOOT.  Well duh it's loot.  Everything is loot in a game like this.  That is like if you went into a bakery and every item was simply labeled "BAKED".  Then there's a LOOT tab and a crafting tab.  But every single thing I pick up (be it something a mob dropped or something I harvest) says it can be used for crafting but it doesn't go in the crafting tab!  That makes no sense to me and I end up selling everything very confused.  A lot of times when I go to sell something the vendor tells me the item is very expensive but they can't give me the amount it is actually worth and that just confuses me even further.Besides these things, it really is an ok game. It's a good looking game with relaxing music.  You can left-click on your map to sort of auto-run to quest givers or whatever.  I just wish it wasn't so grindy and with such frustrating moevment and awful camera.

												As someone who joined in the first week when the game was released as open beta, left for a  while, returned, left again aaaaaand returned again, I think I can do a review of this game.First of all, you may read on other reviews that the game is dying despite decreasing player base. Well, I believe it WAS dying. Since the player base seems to have increased from 1 year ago to now. I see a lot of new players, new guilds, and a lot of ppl online! - Ok, now I can start the usual review.I've tryied some other MMOS when I left this game, but I came back! - Why??This game community is awesome! People are overall really nice and help new players with stuff, it's very easy to forma parties for PvE, there is a good PvP system and there are ALWAYS ppl playing PvP. - So it's really hard to be forced to play alone, as in some other games.There are LOTS of Guildes which you can chose from! There it THE Top Guild, with maxed lvl players ONLY, there are some other Elite Guilds, there are the Nacionality Guilds, like Russian or Brazilian Guilds, Small Guilds, Big Guilds, Active Guilds, Unactive Guilds and Ok Guilds(ENMITY yay!).Basically, there is a Guild for everybody! - Sometimes they require you hit lvl 20, 30 or even lvl 60(max) to join one, but it's actually easy to get to lvl 30 by youself. But the sooner you get to a Guild, the sooner you can ask veteran players for tips more often! - As a lvl 50 who left for a long time I sometimes ask my lvl 60s friends who are still playing lol.About it being a Pay to Win game, it is not! - Maybe if you want to defeat the Top Guild You HAVE to spend some money since some been playing the game since it released and they have AN ENOURMOUS AMOUNT OF TIME of effort by playing the game! - But you can pretty much hit lvl 60 by not paying a cent! - Sorry Katuri! - But the  grinding GETS faster when you pay real money to it! - You can also pay for it in Gold(game currency)! But it's not very cheap. The top players who don't pay real money do it! So here's my first tip lol(I should do it more often). So, I don't agree it's a pay to win game, because there are a lot of new players on the game and just a  small amount of those paid real money.On the other  hand, why not paying real money at some point? Everything well planned and It's even possible to reset your skills WHENERVER you want(as long as you've reached lvl 20)! - If you pay one kind of in game currency of course. The game does not punish the player base who works and studies, because when you leave the game for a certain time, there will be a 2x xp bonus for quite some time, depending on the time you were gone, and it seems that the highest lvl you are, the biggest time the bonus will work for you - it seems that way, but I have not confirmed this yet. The mobs are well made, graphically and functionally, also give us drops that makes sense. I love the class/ skills system,  very good, with lot of options to chose from - not as much as tree of savior, but just enough! You can also  have many characters to your account, which means you can make a character of every class to see which you like most to play with. There are some forced PvP areas, which I really enjoy  it!The bad things about this game are the LAGS, it LAGS SO HARD at certain times! Since last patch it was almost impossible to play with my sorcerer(maybe because I use a lot of skills), but same does not happens with my other characters who don't use as much skills when I go farming. - But it's something they can fix and they do some server maintence(if I didn't write this word right, sorry, not first language and I had a blank on how to write it). 												Final Score 2.5/10Pros: Free to Play. Brought some successful elements from Ragnarok Online, which I enjoyed. Graphics Updated from RO, but.. Good flexibility for hot keys. Many premium items can be obtained in-game, but..Cons: The list of cons is huge.1. Graphics are updated, but .. mediocre by today's photorealistic qualities.2. It is definitely a free to play, but PAY TO WIN, model. In comparing the relative speed at which pay users achieve end game characters and equipment, I would estimate that the pay players are at least 5 times faster to achieve their goals over the average free player. This is evident by players who have started around the same time as me (free player), but have already been miles ahead of me in a matter of days, and I'm not one of the average free players, myself. Likewise, many who play much less, are already left behind in the dust.3. Grinding end game levels will definitely put you on your knees, and that's even with a premium membership. Yea, lots of level grinding. I've heard of a L55 premium sniper complain about it. And when you see L22~26 players grinding on L50+ mobs..and the max level is L60..you know, something is wrong here. When you die, above L20, you are exposed to a 10 minute status ailment called weakness, that halves your attack and defence. The only way to get rid of it immediately is to pay the npcs gold, gold that escalates every level higher than L20 you are. So each time you respawn, you've got to do something else to wait out the weakness time..otherwise cough up (or go premium, which reduces that time to 1 min).4. Earning in-game currency is really horrendous. It's subtle, but with a closer look, you'll see that the loot that you bring in from the monsters, especially true for the higher levels, are not only few, but they hardly add up to buy a single health potion of equivalent level. The rest of the loot can be vended, but only with a time-restricted stall that you need to purchase for more coin..So what does this mean? It simply means, you'll have to farm loot with minimum potions/foods most of the time unless you can successfully fetch a good price for your vended goods. Other times, you'll have to rely solely on the gold earned through quests, and there aren't that many well paying quests after you've completed your main ones. On top of all that, if you've got weakness, you've got to wait it out before you can even start farming for loot.5. PvP everywhere, if you're a friendly, social player like myself, you'll hate the PvP, but that's fine of course, if it's confined to themselves and we PvEer are left to our own entertainment. Sadly, that is not entirely true. The guild system has a lot of perks, like discounted npc prices, better drop rates, better running speed, more defence, more attack and a social community. However, past rank 10, and the guild is prone to other guilds declaring war on it. Some high level players have decided to band together in a certain guild (unnamed, but it could be anyone) in an effort to extort protection tax from smaller guilds so that they will not be PKed outside of towns..it's kind of like how the triads extorts everyday citizens. I guess this is a reflection of the situations real Russians face..but still..THIS IS A BIG DOWNER.6. A massive rip off from the once popular Ragnarok Online. Not that, that in itself is a bad thing, since they had done a lot of concepts right. And most games these days are copied from one another. Big Deal.I could say more, but I have to go.Stay away like the PLAGUE!!

												First Impressions of the game: The color choice and aesthetic is great, many colors, nice feel to the game, though often very bland in areas that are heavily paved (like the main city). The aesthetic shines the most in field areas with a bit of blending between one zone and the next. The second thing I notice, is that the Camera is locked in this psuedo-isometric position, which allows full rotation, but limiting tilt. you can look almost straight down at your character if you wish, or at a slight angle, but you are incapable of looking parallel to the ground, let alone being able to see any trace of sky. (Probably to lessen the system-demand for rendering, and the need for a skybox)The third thing I notice is the obvious Premium service. The game practically screams P2W. I honestly wouldn't mind if there were some benefits to paying players, but what ruined it was the constant self-advertising. The fact that you'd have a Premium / VIP tab right above the hotbar that remains there forever, alongside tabs that would remind you of unspent skill points or stat points. It's also a nuisance to see that little blue 'Premium' tab at the center of your screen as you try to pay attention to skill cool downs and potion counts.The game spends quite a bit of effort reminding you that you 'could' be enjoying the game better if you paid for it.Next on the list is the combat, which is a bit dull. It's your standard auto-attack, use skills when ready, repeat on the next bad guy. What's interesting though, are the passive skills (Talents) that somewhat modify the properties of previously obtained Active skills, though quite a bit of advancement is required.After your first class advancement, you gain this Rift-style 3-option talent tree, in which you can specialize, or become a jack of all trades. Specializing yields you a powerful (or less-than-powerful) active skill at the end of one of the three trees for your class. But frankly, the three-tree system is nothing close to the way Rift handles it, and feels like a dumbed down 'my-first-RPG' experience.The game itself lacks depth from the beginning, and the overall pacing is slow, the quests are un-engaging, and are your standard 'go kill me some wolves for their pelts' ordeal. Occasionally you will get some quests that mess with the props in the environment, or sends you on an errand run across NPCs, concluding in an encounter with an instance (or psuedo-instance)Here's another drawback that really bothered me. The fact that what I had assumed what were instanced dungeons, are actually open to other players. Caves, Underground Libraries, Sewers, were all loaded with players with the same quest, therefor your target monster or drop would also be hunted by several other people, making your 25 Slime kill quest last longer than it really should. My only experience with a true instance were the randomly spawning 'entrances' that whisked you away to an extremely linear and un-engaging mini-dungeon, or one of the Boss Dungeons that I fought with a party of four.Though with that drawback, there is also a certain benefit: The Community. The early-game community is pretty large, everywhere you go you are guarenteed a sighting of another player probably doing the same thing as you, hunting Monsters. Not just one, but many players, all hunting monsters, all having a bit of fun. That's nice. Having lots of players around is nice, which makes this experience slightly more enjoyable. Sort of like you and your friends going to a really really bad theme park, somehow with your friends you were able to squeeze some fun out of it, despite the actual place itself being an uninteresting experience.There are also a few somewhat innovative features: Like castles that could be fought over for guild dominance (though I haven't experienced this feature myself) as well as competitive 'deathmatch dungeons' were you can grind for loot and exclusives materials only if you can survive the onslought of players doing the same thing. (essentially an open PVP dungeon that only allows you to keep your loot if you can escape). Even a raid boss would wonder into town to face the innumerable number of players turning in their quests, leading to a 15-20 player assault on the big ol' boss guy.---In the end the game is colorful and full of life, but also in turn, is uninteresting, even annoying, when alone amongst crowds of other people, all competing for a limited supply of Monsters. The game has it's moments when partied up, and certain aspects are enjoyable, with a few speckles of innovation. But overall, the game feels like an RPG experience lacking in depth, but not lacking in it's P2W ego. 												This is my first negative review, ever.The game itself is actually kind of fun. It's the apparently intentionally confusing pricing in the cash shop and the constant prompts to spend money that warrant the down vote.Most F2P games I have tried are at least roughly based on the dollar. $10 gets you 1,000 coins, or 900, or 1,100 or something close. Here it is 260 coins for $10. This makes it very confusing to figure out how much anything actually costs.For example, crystal keys to open chests are 889 coins for a stack of 10 (used to open random high level chests). So how much is that actually? The answer is $33, or $3.30 to open one chest. You must multiply the item cost by 3.8 to get the dollar price (if buying in $10 increments.)Another example is the item you need to gurantee a combine doesn't fail. They are also over $3. How many ultra-rare reagents you going to see poof before you start buying those?Inventory slots are 36 cents...per slot and per category (armor and weapons go in one bag, potions in another, etc.) You start with 19 slots in each category, the 20th slot is a "buy" button. This makes it $7.20 to buy 20 bag slots that only hold potions (or only armor, etc.). This wouldn't be too bad if the slots could be used for anything.When you die you have 2 choices. Run back from town, or pay to res right there. Which would be tolerable, if every town allowed you to bind. I could find no way to bind in the 2nd town at level 11, died and had to run back from the first town. I died because of a level 59 skeleton that came out of nowhere and started one-shotting people.You can buy a 40% speed mount for (I think) only about $1.60, but that was the only decent deal I could find. I only played to level 12, but from what I'm reading the grind is very bad at 40+ unless you go premium, which is another $12 a month. And going premium does almost nothing to change the intrusiviness of the cash shop.I'm not at all against spending money in these games. I do it all the time. But this whole thing would be more reasonable, and not as confusing if you got 1,000 coins for $10. Maybe their pricing is based on the Rubel or something and will be adjusted before release. As it is now, it's very expensive and intrusive.Bottom line, the game is fun if you have deep pockets.

												Started as a Mage, so I can't really judge in terms of solo difficulty, but every quest up to level 8 at least has you go out, possibly to the opposite side of the current map, kill/loot something, and return back to the starting town again, only to repeat for the next quest. The quest induced yo-yoing is bad enough, but the caves/buildings you are sent to for quests are also shared with the other players, rather than instanced just for you or your party, which can lead to having to struggle against other players in a PvE environment for kills and loot. Admittedly this struggle is pretty standard in MMOs and probably drops off as you level up and the population density declines.But the breaking point for me was a primary quest to kill a Magical Dragonkin. This quest has you go out into an area teeming with aggressive monsters, and find the one and only magical dragonkin, capable of spawning anywhere in that quarter of the map, and kill it. If someone else kills it before you get there, you have to wait for it to spawn and hope you or your party can get to it first.That said, I did find the combat itself enjoyable, with the advertised weaknesses present immediately at the start, and all stats being relevant and plainly explained in tooltips. If you're okay with the questing issues and small inventories, you just might enjoy this. But for the average gamer, this feels like a no go.

												Three months ago I wrote a negative review for royal quest after rewriting my original positive review. I will now go on to expand that negative review.  My last review ended with me summarizing that Royal Quest is pay to win. Which it is, however, it gets worse. The admins, and mods in charge of the forums online are corrupt and protect people at the top of the food chain in game that have cheated their way there. To help people understand the game and the background of what i'm saying i'm going to give a very fast breakdown of all the different levels and parts of the games. levels 1-20 = having fun, playing casually, (taking the bait)levels 20-40 = more challenge, figuring out your class and game goals (getting hooked)levels 40-50 = sinking more time & money into the game you didn't expect (you can't turn back now)levels 50-59 = hoping that the max level 60 will change the game for you (being disillusioned)level 60 = looking to get in a top guild, throw all your time & money at the game (your fate)so all in all how Royal Quest works is this: it lies to you in the beginning, and then once you've invested too much time and money into it to leave, it forces you to join a top guild to succeed. which isn't inherently bad if it weren't for the background corruption of the game. and that corruption boils down to this: monster cards. there is a special item in game that are called monster cards. essentially these cards are very hard to get and make your gear and character very strong. however, there are normal monster cards and then Elite/Boss monster cards which are the hardest monster cards to get but also the strongest. Now when you get to level 60 typically the last thing you do before finishing your character is finding all the normal and Elite/Boss monster cards you need. However it came to light that the leader of one of the strongest guilds in the game had fabricated the majority of his Boss cards some time in past. And to top it off when someone tried to call him out on it, their account was permanently banned. Since that time, people have avoided openly talking about that incident for fear of being permanently banned.  but it gets better. That corrupt guild leader then became a moderator. And as a moderator in any medium your responsibility is to be objective and help the players in the game you moderate. However this corrupt moderator went around and instigated arguments with players (because that's the type of guy he is) and then would chatban people who hurt his feelings.  Recently I was one of those people that got temporarily banned for arguing with him after realizing how corrupt he was. The interesting thing is there are in game rules where you're not allowed to discredit those in authority. however, every single forum post or in game conversation that shows evidence of moderators abusing their power magically gets removed. so when they ask for evidence to our insinuations they know we dont have alot because they took away most of them. To make you smile even more, after this recent happening of me and my friends arguing with the corrupt moderator, i messaged the admin about the whole incident and was promplty temporarily banned for discrediting the corrupt moderator. I then made a forum post about the whole situation and how the moderator was corrupt and broke the silence on all the wrongdoings of the mods and administration and was promptly banned from making forum posts. TL;DR:-this game is dying because of corrupt moderators and admins abusing their powers to cover up illegal stuff they did in the past and only care about the top guilds that those corrupt people are a part of. -There is no way to prevent the people in authority from abusing their powers so they do it all the time and you get punished for even trying to stop them. -don't play this game if you want to have fun. don't play this game if you're bored. don't play this game at all. play WoW or guild wars 2, or Tera. literally any other MMORPG. Thanks for reading, now if you'll excuse me, i'm going to try to get gold in league of legends this season.

Now when you get to level 60 typically the last thing you do before finishing your character is finding all the normal and Elite/Boss monster cards you need. 												I like this game a lot. Step 1 to enjoying it, like any MMO, is finding people to enjoy it with, Once you have that down it is gravy.This is a PVP game but PVP is entirely optional. Don't want to PVP? Don't go into the elenium caves, don't queue for a BG or duel.A very few might say this  game is pay 2 win but in my experience it isn't. There are many things you can buy from the cash shop but free players can buy them too. The cash currency 'reales' is tradable and often bought and sold. The cash shop items are also commonly bought and sold. The most popular being 'blessing scrolls'. There re 3/7/14/30 day varieties and they are basically a 'subscriber' type buff for XP and a few other things. No weapons or armor are cash shop items. Of the items in the cash shop that gives bonuses, equivilent items not in the cash shop are superior. I could buy a +5% HP decoration or I could work for one that can't be bought for cash and has a card slot. It is like this for all items even mounts.The game gets regular updates. In a recent update called "Patch of the Crusader" the class I play as was completely reworked. Before the patch there was a very specific objectively best path to work through. This was because many skills were so weak as to never be used and others being so powerful as to being crutches. This was reworked as to allow multiple ways for the class to be used without one being objectively best. In addition some classes got buffs/fixes/nerfs. As is the far easiest classes to level are the two mages and the sniper.Some people complain about the grind but I have found the grind to not be very bad compared to other MMOs I have played. On the range of "No grind" to "Extreame years long grind" I'd have to put it in the couple months catagory. If you take a mage you can get to level 40 in 3 days and 50 in a week now that enough time has elapsed for people to determine the optimal leveling areas.

This was because many skills were so weak as to never be used and others being so powerful as to being crutches. 												So this will be one of the very few games that actually made me to write an review.Royal Quest is a definitely FUN mmo to play! Altough it's lacking balancing hard, especially between ranged and melee classes. It's a game that features a freedom of building your character (i will mainly focus on mage-sorcerer as i play one). As a sorcerer you can go pve-solo build, pve-support, pve-pvp or purely pvp way. There are three main weapons for a mage and it is spellbook - cheap but medicore ranged attack, scythes - high atk close combat and bracelet+orb combo - medium damage but tons of def (i use bracer+orb). But that's not the end of it, you also got 4 talent trees which specializes in different range of enchantements to your playstyle. On top of that we got equipement that can be imbued with special seals and slots that can fit cards that gives dozens of enchantements. The range of how you want to play is quite diverse which i really like! :)There is no "true crafting" as you could see in other mmos, there is no craft leveling, all you have to do is get a proper recipe and resources that are needed for an item and just craft it. It sounds simple but getting those items requires either lots of gold or lots of grind.Now let's go to badies of this game. The amount of grind is helluva big, without premium it would take me ages to get to 31lvl (as iam now) and i already can feel like even with 2x exp and all that it will still be quite long before i hit 60 (note that i preffer solo style untill i reach like 50).The game is not exactly p2w but it has it's aspects, even tough everything can be purcharsed with normal ingame money, to get this money without any help you either grind like mad or just buy premium currency and sell premium stuff, either way will let you achieve what you want. I personally bought dlc from steam store and im happy with it.It's quite unballanced game, especially very hard start for all melee classes, if you have no money then go mage or archer, both of them got healing spells and can kite harder mobs in early, unlike other melee classes, ofc it's not easy, it still requires skill but it's still much easier than lets say, DK which i started with and dropped at 24 lvl (it took me 2 days to get to 24 on dk and 1 day to get to 24 on mage)Overall i would score this game 7/10, it would be 10/10 if melee classes would be optimized better way. 												This is a pretty unique little gem of a free MMORPG with a somewhat deceptive item shop.Before I start - the item shop IS NOT mandatory.Everything in this game is purchaseable with ingame currency, including the premium currency itself. It is expensive, but you can buy it with in game gold.All in all, this reminds me of some old school point and click action bar MMORPGs similar to Lineage and specifically a game called Ferentus, but a lot more polished and with a very well presented UI and ideas.Summary:-8 classes to choose from (4 in the beginning)-a variety of ways to min/max your attributes-crafting is very important and the only way to get best items (so far)-item shop is very very optional-lots of PVE content, but mostly traditional MMORPG grindy stuff-encourages grind with rewards...lots and lots of rewards-a million ways to customize your character to your taste stats wise-okayish graphics and good sounds effectsAll in all, this is by far one of the better free MMORPGs I played in a long while and has a very fair item shop that is very non intrusive. I definitely recommend this to the fans of the genre and especially those old school players that miss some of the older MMORPGs Check out my longer-ish review here

It's the textures on the ground and such that I'd like to see changed. There are glitches in some spots, and holes and such that aren't a game breaking aspect.Ok, so you got to lvl 20, it slows down a ton, should I quit as a player?HECK NO the main aspect of MMORPG's are the grinding aspects, you play the game to get a higher level, which requires you to do quests, and kill stuff. 												The game plays a lot like an Action-RPG (Torchlight, Diablo etc). It has a decent playerbase (as of Aug.07.14) and seems to take a lot of elements from other popular games, which is not necessarily a bad thing in my opinion since the game is fun to play.Positive Things:+ Great Soundtrack+ Beautiful Graphics+ Very well Optimized+ Varied Landscapes and Scenery+ A whole lot of Different Enemies+ Interesting Lore+ Nice ammount of Loot+ Free 3 Day Premium for Newcomers+ Reales (cash shop currency) can be purchased for in-game gold coins.Negative Things:- A lot of "Fetch Quests"- **Cash Shop and Premium Membership seem to be slighlty "Pay 2 Win", though it just helps you     get EXP and special items faster.- Very small Inventory (can be upgraded with **Reales)- Forced PVP in some areas, which makes it hard to finish some quests because some players just love to kill low-level players.All in all the game is quite fun to play in my opinion, the "Pay 2 Win" aspect isn't as bad as it sounds, Free-Accounts can still have a decent ammount of fun so the game is definitely worth a try, especially if you enjoy Diablo-Like games.** You can buy some stuff in the cash shop and upgrade your inventory space for a currency called "Reales", you can purchase them with real money or you can buy them in the in-game market for in-game gold coins. Buying Reales with in-game money is a lot slower of course and requires grinding but that way you cana ctually buy everything in the cash shop without having to pay real money, so in that sense the game isn't really P2W.

												I don't know what everyone's problem is that is giving negative reviews. Yes it's pay-to-win and is much like other games, but nowdays, there's just so many mmorpgs, it's hard to find anything unique anymore. Just each games has their own style and variations. And as far as pay-to-win goes, that's what you will get when you play a FREE TO PLAY game... The damn makers of this game have to make money SOME HOW to keep the games going... Let me get one thing straight about all the negative reviews.... All these things things the negative reviews are complaining about, is just pretty much what you will find in any typical free to play mmorpg.Now here's my personal opinions on the game so far:Pros:The graphics are beautiful for this type of game, way more beautiful than I expected.The things that you can do to upgrade your gear is a nice feature.So far from the low level maps, I've found these randomly spawned gravestone things that you can click and go into a mini-dungeon (I assume). I've found these quite fun to do because you can get some decent loot from these. I hope there's more in the game!The characters and customization all look quite nice. The faces look just a little weird on some of the options, but other than that, I really like it. There's a decent amount of options for you're character's looks, more than even some mmorpgs I've played. I'm a sucker for character customization, so I really hope they add more features to this.I haven't gotten into crafting (if there is), but what I'm seeing looks like it should be interesting as well.The classes, skills, and stat points when you leveling, all this I really like. There's a unique (to me anyhow) feature for spending your stat points each time you level.The amount of options you are given in the settings (graphics, sound, chat settings etc...) is very nice as well. Games that give you a lot of settings and customization is always nice.Cons-ish:I do hate the click to move, but from all the mmorpgs/games I've played, I'm use to it by now.Bag space is annoying, but I just put things in storage I don't keep any time soon, and sell everytime I go into town. So I never really run into many problems with it.There are pvp zones, I'm not quite sure how it all works, but I look forward to exploring this. From what I've heard though and from what it seems, it doesn't tell you when you are in a pvp zone. Hopefully this stuff will be changed up some.There is a 10min death penalty. After you die, you're stats are decreased for 10mins, but this can be removed for 500g (which is REALLY easy to get) from the respawn points. So it's not a big deal.TLDR? The game has it's ups and downs. To best figure out if YOU like the game, I'd honestly suggest trying it out. Like I was saying earlier though, these negative reviews are kind of BS. Their complaints are stuff you will deal with in almost all free to play games.Every game is going to have at least 1 thing you don't like, after playing games almost my whole like, and 12 years of it being mmorpgs, I've learned you just work around it and deal with it if you like the game enough. No game is perfect :P

												First off I just wanna say, if you are seeing a lot of negative reveiws disregard them and read this one.The most common complaints about the game are its camera angle and the pay to win aspect of the game. 												The game is pretty fun so far, and not quite as easy as I thought it would be. I like the fact that you can play for free. I have played for around 12 hours already, raising the level of my character (mage) to 21 pretty fast. Player base seems friendly in general. The story, while not amazing, is pretty simple to follow and interesting. The look of the game kinda reminds me of Tales of Symphonia, the parts when you were on the world map running around (which, to me, is a good thing).The only problem I have with this game is the fact that while it's free to play, you always, ALWAYS have a "premium" button thingie on your screen, right above your action panel, if you don't have a premium account. It gets really annoying. Also, there are various chests randomly put on the maps, and you can only open them with keys that cost real money. Basically, you can play for free, but you won't have access to everything if you don't pay.In other words, this game is enjoyable, but it's not perfect, especially for people who don't want to spend real money like me. I would still recommend it.
